reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR version:
Kickstarter campaign has (expensive) stage walls for some of the features below.  Game hasn't really improved in a year.  To my disapointment, it's to risky to pay 18 dollars.

Long version:

I purchased this game the first day of release, I wanted the final product to be a decent indie game.   Sure it would have flaws but it would be enjoyable at least.  When I first booted up the game boy was in for a surprise... not for how far along the team was in developing this game, instead for how little and broken everything was; flying was awful, the camera was confusing to use, there was little to do, and everything about the visuals was just ugly.  At first I figure; this game is in early development and it's just needs more work, no worries I'll just watch it develop over time.  However over a year later and I would be lying if I said things got better.  Sure they did add some new NPCs, some new sturctures.  However flying is still broken, the scale of your dragon to the world seems off, and the game doesn't feel anymore improved.

So normally I would brush this game off as a bad purchase and I would have learned a lesson, or maybe still give the dev team the benefit of the doubt.  I honestly don't know that much about game development, so maybe there is more stuff under the hood they are working on that we just don't see yet.  The main problem for me is.  Even after being on the Steam store for over a year.  Red Level Games has decided to start a campaign on Kickstarter.  (To be honest I think they are the only ones to have started on Steam, then moved to Kickstarter.  I know the reverse happens or maybe even they launch at the same time)  It seems really strange to me.  I know games cost money to make, you need to keep people employeed in order to work on a game, you also need a place for them work.  I get it and I don't care that they have this campaign of the side for people who want to help some more.  My real issue is, some of the features listed below (As of the date of writing this review) are now suddenly blocked off by a stage wall.  Even though their Kickstarter Goal is 30K some of the features such as; adding more Dragon body types/species is a 750K milestone on their Kickstarter.

I don't know what Red Level Games was thinking.  This game isn't really popular, it isn't really drawing the attention needed for a Kickstarter to get the majority of it's milestone/stages funded.  It's only popular in a niche market, so the people who would have been willing to donate to the kickstarter probably have already purchased the game and even a smaller percentage of them will  be willing to give even more of their money to this project.

After this Kickstarter I'm now worries on the progress that will be made here.  I feel like it would be a huge risk to anyone now to spend 18 dollars on this game.  However all of this could work out, the game gets finished and it's amazing.  I would be so overjoyed and woul gladly admit I'm wrong.  It's just from where I'm sitting right now... I don't have high hopes.

Early Access Review

Magnificent idea, without a doubt. A game where you take the role of a dragon for no greater reason other than to do dragon-y things. That's really the kind of game i'm craving these days.

That being said, i cannot in any way recommend this game in it's current state. This is VERY early access. Like, SUPER early access. It runs like a snail through molasses(very slowly) on my somewhat competent computer, and there are glitches in the most noticable of places, like that one where your dragon gets stuck tilted at a 45 degree angle from the ground.

Of course, the biggest issue here, the one that really bothers me the most, is that none of the dragons movement feels especially dragon-like, with the arguable exeption of the flying. There is no weight to any of your movement, the fire breath carries all of the force of shining a flashlight on things, and all in all, in it's current state, the game ultimately fails to deliver on the one thing it tries to be: a dragon simulator.

I hope, i truly hope by the grace of the moon that this game becomes something grand. And when it does, i swear i will shower it with all the praise i can muster. For the time being, though, i'm just waiting for this thing to become decently playable.

Oh, the curse of early access games...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Supporting early access games is always risky but I'm glad I chose to support this one. I bought in early to Dragon: The Game out of a love for the concept. Now after a year of checking in I'm happy to report this is one early access which I'm glad I supported. The game is far from finished but I am very encouraged to see the progress that has come about in this past year. We've come a long way from the endlessly exploding peasant on day one. What began as essentially a tech demo is slowly but surely taking a form resembling what I imagined a year ago. Through regular communication and constant updates the devs have slowly but surely been earning my trust. I am very hopeful for what this game can become.

If you're interested in this game please don't let the negative reviews form your opinion. Rather, look at the progress that has been made in the past year and have the expectation that it will be at least another year before the game is ready for launch. Most negative reviews seem to have a common theme regarding the pace of progress despite the devs stating on day one that it would take up to 2 years to reach version 1.0. So far the devs have done exactly what they said they would do, I don't know what more you can ask from them.

If you love the idea of playing as a dragon I'd encourage you to support this title. As with any early access title nothing is guaranteed but after a year of following the development of this title I say the devs deserve a little faith.

***Update to review: 5/3/16***

I've been checking back on this title monthly since my initial review and I feel I need to amend to keep this review honest. Communication from the devs has taken a nose dive since my initial statement. I feel obligated to say that my original statement of regular communication and updates has not held true through the beginning of this year. While I personally still feel very confident in the devs and don't interpret the poor communication in the last few months to indicate anything negative about the game development it must be pointed out to keep this review honest. Communication has improved in April and I hope we get more contact going forward. It's a very small team making this happen and I believe they are incredibly invested in bringing this dream to life but I'm also looking harder than most people probably will, so I hope they improve the frequency of communications to increase visibility and confidence.
That's the largest criticism I can levy currently, over promised on communication. I suspect a driving factor in the communication break down is due to a large overhaul of the game which I will discuss next.

There have been some major improvements/upgrades to the game including switching to a better engine which is a good thing but is essentially switching horses mid stream and brought visible advancement to a halt for some time. The down side to this is it in some regards is like starting from square one. The upside is the capacity for a much better game. What exists currently is still a bare bones shell but it is clearly a superior shell. Communication from the devs recently inclines me to think the big overhaul is about completed and that we'll soon be seeing content additions and performance improvement.

When I speak of the shell of the game improving I don't think I can overstate that. Half of my play time has been from the past week. If I am to be critical of the communication I have to also point to the visibile work done, clearly they have been working on this and what is visibile is much improved. Once the game is a bit more stable and lairs and saved dragon advancements are implemented I can see myself spending quite a bit of time playing this. I REALLY like what I'm seeing with the new incarnation of the game, I see a lot more potential now.

Once the aforementioned content is added to the game I will update this again.

I will update this review with each successive update to the game.

If you find this review unhelpful, tell me why and I will try to fix it.

Revised 6-4-2016

Overview: It is evident from the blog and other resources that the focus right now is on game function and code stability, mostly under the hood stuff, the kind of stuff that matters much more than how pretty it looks. Nobody gives a damn about your Corvette if there is no working engine, and nobody cares about a game with underdeveloped code. In that regard I think Red Level has its priorities straight, and in the play-through my priority at this phase in development was to look at code stability, controls, and interface. Stability and Control score a solid OK, it took me only about five minutes to figure out the basics of movement and flight and after ten was able to fly around without crashing into anything.

Movement & Controll:For those thinking of buying now, the dragon maneuvers like you are flying a helicopter, gravity is irrelevant once you hit the space-bar and continues to be irrelevant after you let go, which causes you to slowly float back down to the surface. The W key allows forward flight, with a momentum dynamic like you would logically expect. Turning is instant and mouse directed, but you will tend to drift like a Ford on ice while cornering even if your dragon faces the desired direction instantly so plan ahead. Be aware that the game does not bind the mouse to the game screen, so long turns in one direction will cause the mouse to drift off screen and will close the window when you click any mouse button.

Combat:Combat is very one sided, both in terms of damage taken, and physical damage dealt since you can only swing your tail to one side or your dragon, so make sure the thing you want to kill is on that side. Fire breath is hard to aim at first so be careful using it on the ground or you will burn yourself before anything around you. Think like an airplane when using this, you want to strafe a target with fire if you can, before landing to collect it.

Navigation:As of right now navigation is line of sight only, you get a look at a map sketch when you first drop in to the game but you have no mini-map in your interface so plan on getting lost. Right now having your bearings doesn't really matter since there is not all that much to do. The map is also fairly small, you'll bump into an invisible wall after about ten minutes flying any one direction.

Quests/Tasks:The game will automatically cycle through a pool of quests that are focused on testing game dynamics like flight, hunting, eating, and exploring (No plot yet, Lore on website). There is no mandate to complete them, but a navigation marker will hover over the relevant task to be completed.

I really wish steam had a netural button. On one hand I want to recomend this game but on the other hand there are reasons why I couldn't.

I'll start with whyI would recomend this game first. Who doesn't dream about an open world RPG where you get to explore, destroy or befriend villages, hunt, build up a lair, raid for loot, take part in ever shifting politics and most importantly you play as a dragon. Now this game really has the potential to be that game someday and that is what the developers have been dreaming of. Since I got this game, I have seen it change quite a bit, but don't take this as it being anywhere near complete.

Now on to bad parts. Currrently the game is very far from complete, as I said, the game does have potenntial but it still has a long, long way to go. The flying mechanics are I have to say a lot better than when I first joined (the flight and flight controls are a lot more stable, thank goodness)  and the textures whilst nowhere near good are at least less of an eyesore than the previous ones (think of Rome II's release and the shining dirt that appeared on that, that was what the previous textures were like.) but the presensce of numerous terrain bugs (floating objects E.C.T.) as well as the lack of things to do in the game in it's current state show that it is a long way from being finished.

Overall I would have to say that I would recomend this game (not really in its' current state) simply because of the potential that is here and it is the potential of the game that just holds it up at the moment. If you're unsure of buying it then perhaps wait fo while for the game to become better but the trickey thing is that the potential can only  be realised through people buying into this early acess which is both the blessing and the curse of early acess.

Now unlike many games that are in 'early acess' I can see that this game isn't just a anouther blatent cashgrab and that the devs really want this game to succeed and I do really see that it is possible for them to be able to pull it off which is anouther reason why I'm recomending it.

Just one more thing I have to say before I end this review, a lot of people are complaining about how the game doesn't look like the videos and screenshots on the store page and how it is in such  a low stage of development compared to the time it's been out, that is because those screenshots and videos are from the previous itteration of this game which fthe devs as far as I know scrapped because they encountered a serious problem with the code, as such this is essentially a whole new game that the devs created  which is why it is in the stage of development it's in.

Now taking onto consideration what I said, go ahead and make up your own mind about whether or not you want to support this game.

Early Access Review

First off, I would just like to address that as the indicator states above, THIS IS AN EARLY ACCESS REVIEW, and will be assessed as such.

Dragon: The Game has great potential, great conceptualization and fantastic ambition. The idea behind an open world MMORPG/RPG that puts you in the position of being one of several fully customizable dragonkin is an amazing push towards online gameplay and single player experiences alike. Putting you at the helm of fully designing, developing and modifying your dragon-sona is something that hasn't been seen in the field.

However, the development team is relatively slow compared to similar major Early Access games such as StarBound or The Long Dark, and more importantly, THE PRICE FOR THE EARLY ACCESS IS RIDICULOUS. Yes, it's wonderful to contribute to new developers, as the gaming field is a large and quickly growing industry that should be open to anyone who so wishes to explore it, but $17.99 for a game that is currently unplayable is not appropriate.

That said, it's hard to see why such a basic game in this current stage is suffering from such a dramatically poor run-state. As you will see in other reviews, along with my own input, you really do need a near top-of-the-line operating system. Don't be fooled by the pretty commonplace system requirements - I apologize for not being able to tell you exactly why it doesn't run, but the performance, even at literally bare minimum skeletal optimizations, runs at about 8 fps at best on your average to decent gaming computer or laptop.

However, I still am very excited to see the completion of the game. I am hoping that this problem array be addressed so that the game doesn't get criticized and ridiculed, but rather fixed and allowed to live up to its full potential. I still support this game, but cannot recommend it at this point in time. I do however, recommend that you keep up with this game!

This is exacty the game I've been waiting years to see.
THIS IS AN ALPHA STAGE GAME, AND IS NOT PERFECT. What game is even perfect anyways?
As of Build 0.77a, the mechanics are getting better.

PROS
-Flying is great and feels nice

I won't put any cons in, but i do have some suggestions for the creator:

SUGGESTIONS:

-Have the camera angle controlled by the mouse, like other 3rd person games (Thinking of Just Cause 2, Batman Arkham series) . Scrolling in and out should control zoom like how it is now, but having to press the scroll button to zoom and move the camera is annoying. ==OR== Have static camera like is now, but have player hold left alt to move camera (like DayZ).
-The running speed should be a little quicker, but that's just a personal preference. Seems a little sluggish as of now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When you purchase an Early Access game you are making a choice. A conscious choice to support and help fund the project, regardless of the potentially difficult road ahead. Early Access games are, obviously, games that are still in development. And every game that you happen to support will be in varying degrees of said development. It's inevitable that you may stumble upon something that is in it's fairly early stages.

Others have brought up the length of time the game has stayed in development. I can assure you there are games that have had more funding which have been in Early Access for longer than D:TG. Most independent dev groups are small. They do not have the funding or the man power to pump out content as much as we may be used to with other titles.

I've owned the game for some time. The progress has been sparse, but it's beginning to pick up speed. The team has been able to acquire better funding and they are beginning to push for content that we would like to see. It's likely that in the near future their team will grow and they will be able to produce better quality content at a much faster pace.

Currently, I have to agree with some of the negative reviews. There's a lot of placeholder material, the control scheme is whack (very uncomfortable, but I believe they are aware of this), and there's not a lot to do. You run around, eat a few deer, and set some villages on fire. It's.. not entertaining. Controlling the dragon with the mouse is just strange. I really wish there was a better way to manage one's camera and flight mechanics.
Yet regardless of my distaste I have high hopes for the future.

The dev team seems passionate about this project. There's not many games out there like D:TG. It's kind of one of those titles we always wished for. But to make that happen we have to help support it. Constructive feedback is the most beneficial to all. Not some cheap jab at an obvious problem without offering any form of solution or critique. If we sit here and  endlessly we're going to do nothing but doom the title ourselves, and then try to pass it off as the dev team's fault. It's a two way street with the commitment made with early access.

They plan a lot for this game. I'm excited for the future.

Early Access Review

After getting my early access key, I jumped straight on the computer and played the game for a bit. It's a good start, but here are the first things I feel like are missing from playing the game for the first time:
- Directional controls are a bit funky. When I try to walk backwards, that's what I expect. Not the weird twirl that my dragon does, facing me away from what I'm fighting.
- Not sure who is losing health, me or the wolf. Perhaps putting the health numbers of the player in a different color?
- There's no good sense of aiming. A crosshair or something similar would be extremely helpful.
- Looking around is clumsy. When the mouse is in the center of the screen, the camera is not. This is a huge problem and could also help with the aiming issue.
- Quest markers were really all over the place. It told me to go kill a deer and the marker was floating 100 feet over the ocean.
- Lag. Obvious thing to fix.
- Upgrading stats wasn't working. I could only update the passive skills at the bottom.
- Movement speed is terrible. I know that you eventually level up speed, but the starting walking speed is absolutely horrendous, there's almost no point to walking, except that flying is the same. I feel like it takes a long time just to fly over to the next wolf that I should be walking towards.

After a quick play, these are the issues that I noticed immediately. I'm sure that there's a lot to get done, but this game has a ton of potential. With work and passion, this could be a fantastic game. Good luck, developers!

Just fly back to the inner part of the map and you'll be fine.

Now for hunting. You can find animals and people on the map, but since it's early access, theres barely anything. You can kill them by clawing, which sends your enemies into a massive cloud of blood, then seeing a bunch of stacked red, shiny bricks on the ground. hold E while oer them to eat. You can also breathe fire to kill and destroy things. When you kill something with fire, the meat is flaming.

Some things to consider.
If you can deal with a couple bugs and a few problems, that's what's going to happen. BUT, do not doubt this game and think its a waste of money. keep it to yourself. You'll probably change your mind after the update, which is going to be massive as far as I can tell. Yes, this game is cool and for all the dragon RP lovers out there. I hope to see many people post positive reviews, because this game, even in early access, is really cool.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since this game was just released as a super early  alpha recently, it's not completed (obviously). There's not much to do and not much to see. It's a starting point and the devs are pretty keen on working on stuff (and did some pretty immediate bug fixes so that's a pretty good sign). Here's the preliminary barebones review, to be updated as the game does.

UPDATED - NOVEMBER 12TH, 2014

Notes: It's really hard to actually split some of these things into pros and cons at this stage of development because everything, depending on what you value or how 'done' it is could go in either category. Until the game is further along, I'll keep the various points in a numbered list here, irrespective of pro or con.

ONTO THE THINGS--

1. Lots of potential.

You're in a sandbox world as a dragon and theoretically, you get to help shape the landscape (metaphorically). Hopefully before too long we'll be able to interact with humans, have enemies, etc. At the moment, as of the latest hotfix, there is a lot more life to the map. Humans (some that attack you with spears), cows, deer, trolls, move houses, lots of trees-- It's not much yet, but it's getting there, especially compared to what it was on release day.

2. Graphics aren't half bad though not spectacular. A little dated at the moment.

They'll probably get better and could use some optimization work (but so could the whole system and that typically comes with time). There are still some problems with screen resolutions and rendering, but killing something no longer causes the Peasant of Doom glitch (I.E. killing a peasant would cause them to erupt with red blood gibs that formed an FPS-murdering column to the point where you ought to restart your game and think about what you how murdering peasants is apparently bad). Also the status bars and some of the buttons (like the map selection button that looks a bit like a loading screen) could use some polish.

3. Dragons are customizable and can age.

While that's not fully implemented yet, it's on the way, bro. There is some current customization and stats (but they don't seem to have much effect at the moment). At the moment, customization is limited to changing colors, but entire different species of dragon and adaptations are planned.

4. Linux and Mac versions.

They were released pretty quickly along with the recent hotfix. There seems to have been some issues with getting the Linux version to play straight from Steam for some users, but the devs posted a workaround for it in the meantime while they fix up their Linux upload.

5. Very active and respectable developers.

They've been very active in the forums, very polite in how they handle criticism and feedback of all sorts, and have shown zero leaning towards any sort of censorship. They're chill with anyone wanting to review or add suggestions or doing letsplays. They're also working on cataloguing known bugs to quash as they can while working on implementing new mechanics. So far, they've been very on top of things and have been amicable. They are some of the best behaved Early Access developers I've ever run across.

6. Unity engine.

Not really a con unto itself so much as Unity can be a buggy pain but it can also do some cool stuff. There are people that really don't like the Unity engine. That's entirely fair. However, it can be done well. In the meantime, it's going to be its own pain in the  while the devs work to tame it. It also just doesn't seem to like some computers which can be a real off-putter to some gamers.

7. Nothing much at the moment to do.

You can fly around (the mechanics of that were improved with the recent hotfix, but it can still be a bit wonky-- I'm bad at it and faceplant into the ground a lot). You can light things on fire, especially now that there's a lot more to burn: several villages from small to large (though some are unpopulated), a small amount of people (women with spears and screaming men), trees, and apparently trolls. You can also eat the gibs that drop to help you grow. Unfortunately, there's nothing more than that yet. That and the growth mechanic isn't exactly implemented yet either and it needs a lot of tweaking.

8. The tutorial is virtually non-existent.

A tutorial itself hasn't really been implemented but some helpful hints when you start a world are shown on the screen. Unfortunately, due to earlier mentioned resolution problems. There is a list of current controls pinned in the Steam forums, but that's another temporary workaround until things can be more solidly implemented.

9. No save/load feature.

When you start a world, you always start fresh. You cannot save and you cannot load. This is only temporary, but at the moment, there isn't much you'd want to save anyway. Your dragon's stats at the moment are carried over through the playthroughs anyway. Just every time you start the game, you basically refresh the map so you can burn the same villages over and over again.

10. Pricy, somewhat.

For the level of early access that it is, it's a bit high, but they made no pretense about how much it would be when they posted their pricing model in the forums here on Steam. However, in the long run and for being a part of the development process, that's not so bad. It just depends on what's worth it more to you, the customer, to pay now to be part of the development process or to pay later (at a possibly higher cost) when the game is more complete or entirely complete. The developers have stated that they are encouraging people who aren't sure or who have been burned by Early Access debaucles before to please wait to purchase until their trust can be earned.

Early Access Review

Please keep in mind that this is an alpha review! If you're looking for a game to play for hours and hours, this is not it.
There's barely anything to do at the time being, apart from flying, igniting stuff and eat the occasional mammal. No Quests, nothing to craft or to claim as loot for your lair so far.

Yet, this looks great!

Taking off and landing works really great and easy already, the controls are very intuitive, (although a little buggy still).
The graphics look overall nice and shiny, and the engine runs stable as far as I can tell, didn't encounter a crash or major glitch so far.
The camera allows for 'dragon barely visible'  to almost first person distance and can be turned 360, you can adore your dragon from every possible angle and distance.
The concept and idea is brilliant and support-worthy.
Flying above the land is really fun already, the speed to map size ratio is nice and you feel like you really own the land when dashing over it.
I hope they'll include mating in some form though :3

In this stage, I can only rate it  Dragon/10.

If you're looking for a game that's almost finished, you'll be disappointed in this, but, if you want to support and be part of what looks awesome... join!

if u have problems here is what they have seid to do:

Getting into the game:
1. Open Game

4. Click NEW GAME
5. Enter world name (does not save yet)
6. Click on map

Deleted dragon problems:
There are two different solutions I have seen so far. The first:

1. Go to Program Files
2. Open SteamApps
3. Open Dragon
4. Delete the Characters and Characters.drg files

Or:

1. Open Steam Game Library
2. Right click on Dragon: The Game
3. Open Local Files tab
4. Browse Local files, but don't do anything else yet.
5. Uninstall the game from Steam
6. Delete the Dragon folder from WinExplorer
7. Delete the file from the Recyle Bin
8. Reinstall Dragon

Early Access Review

I am not an experienced reviewer. I am less than serious much of the time, and usually provide little reason as to why I enjoy or not enjoy a game. So yeah, take that and do with it what you will.

While I haven't really played an hour yet, I think I can say I've seen all there is to see at the time period I am writing this in.

First off, I made a dragon named Rek'tuum.
Surprising lack of Elder Scrolls dragons, I assume that's only because not many Dovahkiin have joined the ranks of the dragons yet.

While I do have great FPS on fullscreen maximum graphics, the game will crash at random times. Perhaps because I was a server owner (as it had not done so in singleplayer) or maybe it's just a multiplayer thing, I am unaware. Also, there are several bugs and/or glitches that I have noticed that probably everyone else has noticed but I will not refrain from bringing to light (possibly, bringing them to light again.) The main glitch I see is how flying at extreme angles causes the player-dragon to either land at that angle, land at the angle while ricocheting away, or land at another even more extreme angle. Not gamebreaking unless you start getting turned sideways, at which point flying is nigh-impossible without some adjustments. More problems occur in multiplayer, though they may be client-side and my computer is just hallucinating, including other player-dragons floating in midair and walking in place beside one another, or player-dragons not floating in midair and walking in place beside one another. Furthermore, when typing large sentences or multiple sentences in chat, instead of simply continuing on the second or third (or forth or five etc.) line, the box will start removing the beginning of the text being typed. Also, saying nothing still flashes your name on the chatbar, which is a little awkward.

Still, while the paragraph explaining those few glbugitches is quite large, the effect they have on the player player-dragon is not particularly gamebreaking. I'd definitely recommend it, perhaps even more in the future when bugs are squashed, glitches are exploited for humor rather than menace, and new features are added.

Do want.

I bought this game 2 days ago, and so far have enjoyed playing it, even if it fairly simple SO FAR.


BUGS:


-For me and others, when in online mode, where you spawn, there are a few trees, and some really small people, if you burn them, it causes the game to get INCREDIBLY laggy, and you then have to exit the game and restart it to fix the problem.

-When flying, making a hard right will cause your dragon to become permenantly tilted to the right, screen/camera too, and it makes it increbibly hard to fly and walk, and look around, this also must be fixed by restarting the game.


DISLIKES:


-Me and others I have talked to on the online servers have expressed their frustration that while typing, when using the spacebar key it causes your dragon to jump. It wouldn't be much of a problem if when typing and pressing space TWICE before your dragon lands the first time it causes it to jump off and fly off of whatever you may be perched on. If you're flying, then it's not a big deal.

-There is NO SOUND. You're probably working on that, I'm just saying I love dragons and especially their sounds, so whenever you could get that inw ould be great.



LIKES:


-For an early access game, I really appreciate what you have so far, it's fantastic.

-Love the online mode, not many people, but it's fun to fly aroudn with them when there are a few. It's very simple to set up a room and host it.

-Dragon's flying animation is very nice.


IDEAS:


-Maybe center the dragon more in the middle of the camera?

-Perhaps make the dragon larger? I think that would make it a bit nicer, especially since you get to choose different ages, so the sizes depends on the age, but I've done both YOUNG DRAKE and ANCIENT, and there is no size difference that I can see.

What exists of the land and textures looks really good, and there is already a nice variety of animated mob types with in the beta (humans, animals and different monsters). Given that we already have the framework for both single- and multi-player games, a bit of diversification of dragon types/abilities, and a fair bit of world-building on the dev's site, this game could truly be built up into something awesome.

Ragdoll was implemented - welcome to 1999

And fly around.

Edit: Now a EULA change.
I would not buy this if given the choice again. At least the devs of DragonFlight try to work with the players rather than stifling dissent.

This game is going nowhere fast.

No change in the game play.

Still nothing worthy.
